+use arrow::bitmap::Bitmap;
+use arrow::datatypes::Schema;
+use arrow::error::Result;
+use arrow::record_batch::RecordBatch;
+use evaluator::{Filter, Projector};
+use expression::Expr;
+
+/// Projector implementation using functions in ```gandiva_ffi```
+struct GandivaProjector {}
+
+impl GandivaProjector {
+    pub fn new(schema: Schema, exprs: Vec<Expr>) -> Result<Self> {
 
 Review comment:
   what is the schema argument here? the schema before or after the projection? Comments on the arguments would be good.

liurenjie1024 commented on issue #4308: ARROW-5315: [Rust] Gandiva binding interface design
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4308#issuecomment-493054451
 
 
   @sunchao @andygrove 
   Thanks for the review, just added some comments and examples following reviews. 
   As I said in doc, the first version will use bindings to gandiva c++ implementation, so we need to add c interface in cpp module, just similar to the jni interface for java bindings. Also to build and run rust implementation, it requires gandiva c++ implementation installed. 
   
   These two points above are my concerns with this approach, and how do you think about this?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

   ```
   let projector = gandiva::evaluator::GandivaProjector::new(schema, expressions);
   project.eval(record_batch);
   ```

andygrove commented on issue #4308: ARROW-5315: [Rust] Gandiva binding interface design
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4308#issuecomment-500669435
 
 
   @liurenjie1024 Sorry for the delayed response, I haven't had time to work on Arrow lately. If there is a way for the top level build to default to just building the pure Rust crates that would be best, and the user can specify extra commands/options to build the gandiva support. It would also be good if a docker image can be provided for running the build (maybe that partially already exists for the C project?)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

users@infra.apache.org

   @andygrove Recently I'm reading gandiva code and llvm-sys crate. It seems that effort of  rewriting gandiva with pure rust is not as huge as I think. I'll spend more time to do investigation and comparison.

nevi-me commented on issue #4308: ARROW-5315: [Rust] Gandiva binding interface design
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4308#issuecomment-500746947
 
 
   > @andygrove Recently I'm reading gandiva code and llvm-sys crate. It seems that effort of rewriting gandiva with pure rust is not as huge as I think. I'll spend more time to do investigation and comparison.
   
   @liurenjie1024 while a native rewrite/port of gandiva sounds good, we have to be cognisant of the effort it might require to keep it up to date with the cpp implementation. We're already behind spec (or still haven't implemented some parts), and there's discussions about releasing a 1.0.0; which might require up to do some catching up.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

paddyhoran commented on issue #4308: ARROW-5315: [Rust] Gandiva binding interface design
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4308#issuecomment-500811485
 
 
   To play devil's advocate, a native Rust Gandiva would be much easier to maintain from a build and infrastructure point of view and would make it easier to attract new contributors.
   
   Maybe we should summarize where we are behind spec on the wiki, I plan to start contributing again soon (work and relocation of family) and would like to focus on this.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

nevi-me commented on issue #4308: ARROW-5315: [Rust] Gandiva binding interface design
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4308#issuecomment-500826328
 
 
   @liurenjie1024 I understand, my comment was more for 'core' arrow work, as we have finite resources in contributors; I was suggesting that we could perhaps allocate more effort to 'catching up', so that a 1.0.0 becomes easier.
   
   @paddyhoran I hear you, I'll list what I think we're behind on (perhaps on a Google doc that we can transfer to the wiki?). I'll share it on the mailing list when I've gotten to the task.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

   FWIW, it seems like people are being successful using Rust to write compiler systems. It's not out of the question that Gandiva-in-Rust could become the default implementation used in C++ someday, similar to https://github.com/weld-project/weld

wesm commented on issue #4308: ARROW-5315: [Rust] Gandiva binding interface design
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4308#issuecomment-500851283
 
 
   Also, the 1.0.0 release is about the protocol version -- we want to make sure that we have at least two implementations that are reference implementations of the 1.0.0 protocol, with integration tests, so I don't think Rust is blocking anything, but it would be nice to see Rust as a first-class participant in the integration tests at some point
